content: The "Grand Jury Reform Act of 1998" may be cited as the official title of the Act. It pertains to the reform of grand juries. The "Grand Jury Reform Act of 1998" amends Rule 6 of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure to include instructions on the rights, responsibilities, and duties of the grand jury, such as inquiring into criminal offenses, calling witnesses, and requesting evidence. The "Grand Jury Reform Act of 1998" amends Rule 6 of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure to include instructions on the rights, responsibilities, and duties of the grand jury, such as inquiring into criminal offenses, calling witnesses, requesting evidence, and other appropriate rights and duties determined by the court. The amendments also include provisions for the court to investigate any violations of secrecy and appoint counsel for such investigations. The "Grand Jury Reform Act of 1998" amends Rule 6 of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure to include instructions on the rights, responsibilities, and duties of the grand jury. It also allows the court to appoint counsel to investigate violations of secrecy and provides notice to witnesses about their rights, including the right to counsel, privilege against self-incrimination, and information about the grand jury investigation. The "Grand Jury Reform Act of 1998" amends Rule 6 of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure to include instructions on the rights, responsibilities, and duties of the grand jury. Witnesses subpoenaed to appear before a grand jury have the right to counsel during questioning in the grand jury room. Counsel can be retained by the witness or appointed by the court if the witness is determined to be financially unable to do so. The "Grand Jury Reform Act of 1998" allows witnesses to have counsel present during questioning in the grand jury room. Counsel can be retained by the witness or appointed by the court if the witness is financially unable to obtain counsel. The appointed counsel can only advise the witness and cannot address the grand jurors or participate in the proceedings. If the appointed counsel violates these rules, the court has the power to intervene. The court may remove counsel for violating rules or to prevent delays in grand jury activities. The attorney must disclose exculpatory evidence to the grand jury. Failure to do so could lead to a motion to dismiss the indictment. The court may dismiss the indictment if evidence could lead the grand jury not to indict. Defendants are entitled to examine grand jury transcripts and statements before trial. Defendants are entitled to examine and duplicate grand jury testimony or evidence that is considered exculpatory or material to the defense, except if it endangers any witness. Amendments are made to Section 3500(e) of title 18, United States Code.
